newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Netanyahu, Arafat meet to clinch Hebron deal.
newsitem.headline: Netanyahu, Arafat meet to clinch Hebron deal.

text.p: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian President Yasser Arafat held a summit on Wednesday in an effort to clinch a long elusive Hebron deal.

The two men went into talks at the Erez crossing between Israel and the Gaza Strip for a meeting officials said could culminate in the initialling of an agreement to extend Palestinian rule to most of Hebron in the West Bank.
"The atmosphere is positive and upbeat," government spokesman Moshe Fogel told Reuters by phone from Erez.
U.S. Middle East envoy Dennis Ross, who hours earlier announced the summit, was mediating at Erez along with other American officials.

"We hope there will be a signing tonight. There are still some minor issues which need to be resolved," PLO negotiator Mahmoud Abbas told reporters after efforts on Tuesday to clear final hurdles ahead of the summit.
"The chance that we will finish this evening exists but it is not guaranteed," Netanyahu told reporters after the summit was announced on Tuesday.

Hebron, a West Bank flashpoint, is home to 400 militant Jewish settlers and 100,000 Arabs. It was due to be given self-rule 10 months ago but violence, security concerns and Israel's change of government in June delayed the pullback.
By sealing the Hebron deal Netanyahu will be doing what he and his right-wing Likud party said they would never do -- cede part of the biblical Land of Israel to Palestinians.
In Jerusalem, nearly 200 settler leaders who oppose the Hebron deal called on members of Netanyahu's cabinet to vote against it.

"The agreement is a suicide pact," David Wilder, a spokesman for Hebron's settlers, told Reuters. "It's like having somebody hold a gun to your head and having somebody else helping to pull the trigger."
At least seven of 18 cabinet members have said they will oppose the agreement when it comes up for government approval.
"I think Netanyahu has a solid majority for the agreement," his communications chief David Bar-Illan told CNN television. "Most ministers will vote for it."

Hebron is holy to Moslems and Jews who regard the Tomb of the Patriarchs as the burial place of the biblical Abraham. The tomb, the town's Jewish enclaves and about a fifth of Hebron's Arabs will remain under Israeli control.

Palestinian police will deploy in the rest of Hebron, the last of seven Palestinian towns that were to be turned over to Palestinian self-rule under a 1995 interim peace accord signed by the previous Israeli government.
